reference: Volume Four, Issue Forty-Three, File 1 of 27
title: Phrack 43 Introduction
historical_context: This issue of Phrack comes at a time when the hacking community was increasingly at odds with corporate and governmental entities regarding copyright and intellectual property rights.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture.
short_summary: The introduction to Phrack 43 critiques the unethical practices of security professionals and corporations regarding copyright violations, while setting the tone for the issue's content.
summary:
In the introduction to Phrack 43, Erik Bloodaxe expresses frustration with the blatant disregard for copyright laws exhibited by various security professionals and corporations. He recounts specific cases, including the Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) and BT Tymnet, where individuals within these organizations have unlawfully distributed Phrack without proper registration. Bloodaxe highlights the irony of these entities, which are supposed to protect others' rights, violating the very principles they advocate. He emphasizes that only a select few within the professional realm have shown respect for Phrack's intellectual property, underscoring a broader critique of the ethics in the security industry.

Bloodaxe's tone is both confrontational and sardonic, as he challenges the notion that hackers are the only unethical players in the digital landscape. He calls out the hypocrisy of security professionals who fail to uphold the laws they are sworn to protect, suggesting that the hacking community is not the only group with questionable morals. This introduction sets the stage for the rest of the issue, which promises to delve into various topics relevant to the hacking community, including technical guides and cultural commentary, all while maintaining a critical lens on the industry's ethical standards.
